Cassation (avec renvoi). — En cas de cassation avec renvoi, le Juge devant lequel l'affaire est renvoyée doit statuer au fond. Il ne peut renvoyer l'affaire au Juge qui avait connu de l'affaire en première instance, ce dernier étant dessaisi par le jugement qu'il a rendu. (Cass. 5 Mai 1900, p. 203).
Cassation (Fausse application de la loi).- L'art. 352 du C.P. relatif aux circonstances atténuantes ne concerne que les peines principales.

Le Juge ne peut, en conséquence, s'il constate l'existence de circonstances atténuantes, infliger la peine accessoire de la mise sous la surveillance de la police pour un terme inférieur au minimum fixé par l'article qu'il applique.
Doit donc être cassé, le jugement qui, dans le cas prévu par l'art. 301 du C.P. (récidive de vol), prononce la surveillance de la police pour deux mois.
(Cass. 19 Janvier 1901, p. 279).
Cassation (Nullité substantielle): – 1° Ne constituent pas des nullités substantielles donnant ouverture à Cassation :

(a) Le fait qu'une citation en matière de diffamation par la voie de la presse ne reproduit pas les propos diffamatoires, si, à raison d'un renvoi précis aux passages incriminés, le prévenu n'a pu se méprendre sur les articulations considérées comme diffamatoires, et a pu dès lors préparer sa défense.

1) Le fait, par une sentence d'appel confirmant un jugement de 1re instance et appliquant les articles qui y sont insérés, de ne pas reproduire le texte des dits articles. c) Le fait que le juge du fond aurait fixé arbitrairement et seulement d'une façon approximative les dommages et intérêts accordés à la partie civile, le juge du fond statuant souverainement et sans contrôle de la Cour de Cassation sur l'existence du préjudice allégué et sur l'étendue des dommages intérêts. d) Le fait de ne pas admettre l'offre de prouver les faits diffamatoires quand ceux-ci sont imputés à une personne autorisée à recueillir de l'argent pour organiser une fête de bienfaisance, semblable autorisation n'étant pas attributive de la qualité de fonctionnaire public. e) Le fait par un jugement de ne pas faire mention de la lecture du rapport (C.I.C. art. 184) et de la délibération du tribunal quand ces mentions sont constatées par la feuille d'audience. f) Le fait par le jugement qui condamne pour diffamation, de ne pas constater que le prévenu a agi de mauvaise foi, l'existence de la mauvaise foi se trouvant tacitement affirmée par la constatation du même délit.
(Cass. 3 Mars 1900, p. 4).

2° Le fait de ne pas avoir entendu le prévenu le dernier (C.I.C. arts 135, 160, 205) ne constitue pas une nullité substantielle, donnant ouverture à cassation, dans le cas où il est établi que le Ministère Public n'a modifié en rien ses premières conclusions et que le prévenu n'a pas demandé la parole le dernier.
(Cass. Avril 1900, p. 237).

3º Ne constitue pas une nullité substantielle de la procédure (C. I. C. art. 220) le fait d'avoir cité un prêtre cophte comme prévenu devant une juridiction répressive sans lui avoir fait parvenir l'exploit par l'intermédiaire du Patriarcat.

4° (I) Un jugement condamnant pour faux doit, à peine de nullité, indiquer explicitement par quel moyen le faux a été commis. Ainsi, un jugement qui fait mention de plusieurs moyens de faux, sans indiquer celui qui a motivé la condamnation, doit être cassé. Il en est de même d'un jugement qui ne précise pas les éléments constitutifs de la complicité.

(II.) Quoiqu'en matière correctionnelle un prévenu ne doive pas nécessairement être assisté d'un avocat, constitue néanmoins une violation des droits de la défense, donnant ouverture à cassation, le fait, par un tribunal, de n'avoir pas entendu l'avocat de l'inculpé, qui, absent au commencement des débats, s'est présenté et a demandé la parole après le réquisitoire du Minis-

Expropriation of immovables:- 1º. A claim that a seizure of immovable property in execution be set aside, on the ground that the instrument in virtue of which the creditor has issued execution has previously been set aside (otherwise than on the hearing of an opposition under Art 548 C. C. C. Pr.) may not be made incidentally in the course of the hearing of the application for judicial sale of such property.
Such a claim, like all others which concern the substance of the creditor's alleged right, can only be made in the form and subject to the conditions prescribed in Arts. 548 follg. C.C.C. Pr.

The only questions, which may be raised in the course of the proceedings for a judicial sale, are those which do not concern the substance of the execution creditor's claim, e.g., those relating to procedure.
(Trib. Alexandria, 4 June 1900, p. 28).

2º. In the case of expropriation of immovable property (Arts. 537 follg. C.C.C. Pr.), when a second adjudication takes place in consequence of a higher bid (surenchère), no other higher bid for the same property can be received after this second adjudication is closed.

Art. 584 C.C.C.Pr., which enacts that the second adjudication is to be held in accordance with the rules followed in the first sale, only applies to the formalities of the sale, and not to the right of making a higher bid conferred by Art. 575 of the C.C.C. Pr.
(App. 10 January 1901, p. 217).
3º. A plaintiff, in whose favour provisional execution of a judgment given by default has been granted, is thereby entitled to claim the expropriation of the defendant's immovables.

Forgery:- 1º. A person who has committed a forgery, and has afterwards uttered the forged document, may be prosecuted for such uttering, although criminal proceedings with regard to the offence of forgery are barred by prescription.
2º. Where there is falsification of an instrument ipso facto void, there is no forgery punishable by the law, because there is no possibility of prejudice.

More especially, the act of falsifying a private instrument, purporting to be a sale of an immovable, does not come within the scope of the criminal law, when it appears from the instrument itself that a gift was made under pretence of a sale.
3. A person who as defendant in a civil cause relies upon a forged document, is guilty of uttering a forgery, and each time that he so relies upon it, he commits a distinct offence.

However, if in the course of this trial the other party commences improbation proceedings with respect to the document in question, the series of offences of uttering the forgery must be held to have terminated at the moment when the declaration was made at the registry in accordance with Art. 273 C. C. C. Pr., and it is from this moment that the period of prescription of criminal proceedings begins to run.

8º. A judgment is liable to Cassation, if it sentences a person as a recidivist for a subsequent misdemeanour under Art. 18 P. C., without indicating the nature of the previous offences, the penalties awarded, and the dates of conviction, in order to show that the conditions required by the said article are fulfilled.

These indications are necessary to enable the Court of Cassation to determine whether or not the law has been rightly applied, and a mere reference to the extract from the record of previous convictions delivered by the criminal identification office (Bulletin du casier judiciare) is insufficient.
(Cass. 2 December 1900, p. 240).

9º. The civil claimant cannot rely, as a ground for Cassation, upon the fact that the Court of Appeal did not observe the rules laid down in Art. 184 C. Cr. Pr., concerning the order of pleadings. The law does not require these rules to be observed under pain of nullity, consequen-. tly the Civil claimant cannot set up in his own favour the fact that they were not observed, when he has not thereby suffered any prejudice.
The same principle applies with regard to the failure of the Court of Appeal to hear the statement of the accused person.
(Cass. 22 December 1900, p. 243).

10'. It is not permissible to raise before the Court of Cassation the objection that the evidence of witnesses was not given upon oath, if the point was not taken at the hearing of the case either in First Instance or on Appeal. (Ibid). after the declaration of opposition has been entered (in addition to any extension of time allowed for distance). Consequently a judgment given by default, on the hearing of an opposition, is liable to Cassation if such hearing commenced less than one clear day after the declaration of opposition was entered.
(Cass. 23 March 1901, p. 246).

13°. When a judgment, by which a summary judge has declined jurisdiction, since the case is primâ facie one of crime (Art. 173 C. Cr. Pr.), is reversed on appeal, the summary judge before whom the case is brought afresh is bound by the decision given on appeal.

If he declines jurisdiction a second time, and this last decision is appealed against, the Court before which the appeal is brought must allow that the appeal will lie and determine the case on its merits by evocation. If therefore such Court decides that no appeal will lie in the circumstances mentioned, this decision is subject to Cassation, as vitiated by a substantial nullity.
(Cass. 27 April 1901, p. 281).

14°. A judgment given by a Court irregularly composed is liable to cassation. The fact however that the President of a Tribunal had forwarded to the Parquet a charge of attempted bribery, sent to him by one of the magistrates of his Tribunal whom it had been attempted to bribe, does not of itself render it improper for such President to preside at the hearing at which sentence for the attempted bribery is passed; for, having expressed no opinion on the case, there are no grounds for recusing him.
15°. It is not necessary that the designation of the offence punished should appear in the operative part of the judgment; it is sufficient if such designation is contained in the motives.
(Ibid).

Cassation (with order for new trial).- When the Court of Cassation makes an order for a new trial, the Court to which the case is sent down to be re-tried must hear and determine the action upon its merits, and not refer it to the Court which tried the charge in First Instance, since the powers of such latter Court were exhausted by the judgment it had previously pronounced.

11°. It is not permissible for a Criminal Court to decide upon the merits of a charge after merely reading the documents in the case, without hearing witnesses at the trial. The fact that witnesses were not heard in Court constitutes a substantial nullity affording a ground for Cassation.
(Cass. 29 December 1900, p. 319).

12º. Arts 130 and 159 C. Cr. Pr. lay down that the making of opposition to a judgment by default implies citation to appear at the “next sitting of the Court.” But having regard to Art. 127 C. Cr. Pr. the words “next sitting of the Court,” must be understood to mean the first sitting which takes place one clear day at least

(d) When the Court which tried the case refused to admit evidence of the truth of defamatory statements made concerning a person who had been authorised to collect subscriptions for the organisation of a féte for charitable purposes: for such authorisation could not constitute the person in question a public official.

2º. The fact that the accused person was not heard last (C. Cr. Pr. Arts. 135, 160, 205) does not constitute a substantial nullity affording a ground for Cassation, in a case where it is shewn that the State Representative had not in any way modified his original conclusions, and that the accused did not claim the right of final reply.
(Cass. 7 April 1900, p. 237).

3º. The fact that a citation to appear in answer to a charge before a Criminal Court was served directly on a Coptic priest, instead of such service being effected through his Patriarchate, does not constitute a “subtantial ground of nullity of the proceedings,” within the meaning of Art. 220
C. Cr. Pr.

4º. A judgment of conviction for forgery must, under pain of nullity, precisely specify the means by which the forgery was committed Thus a judgment which mentions several acts which would constitute the offence of forgery, but does not specify upon which of such acts the conviction was based, is liable to Cassation.
So also is a judgment, which does not clearly indicate the circumstances relied on by the Court as rendering a person punishable as an accomplice.

5º. Although the assistance of an advocate is not obligatory in trials for misdemeanour, nevertheless it must be held that the right of free defence is violated, and that there is consequently a ground for Cassation, when the Court refuses to hear an advocate who appears for the accused person. This is so even where such advocate was not present when the trial was commenced, and did not appear and ask to be heard until after the final speech of the State Representative, provided that the Court had not already risen, or commenced the hearing of a fresh case.
The contention that in the circumstances mentioned the hearing was already closed, is not admissible. (Ibid).
6º. The provisions of the C. C. C. Pr. (Arts.
223 follg. and 226), which regulate the formalities laid down for expert enquiries in a civil cause, do not apply to expert enquiries ordered in a criminal cause.
Consequently the fact that the procès-verbal of the taking of the oath by the expert has not been served on the accused does not constitute a ground for Cassation.
(Cass. 15 December 1900, p. 171).

7º. A judgment of conviction must, under pain of nullity affording ground for Cassation, state the day upon which the offence was committed, or at least contain such an indication of the time at which such offence took place as to make it clear that proceedings are not barred by prescription.
(Cass. 15 December 1900, p. 206).

Assault and battery.-1°. The results of the accused person's own act ought alone to be taken into consideration in appreciating the consequences of assault and battery, which are of a kind to aggravate the punishment (P.C. Arts. 215, 218, 219).

In consequence, an assault, which has occasioned a permanent infirmity solely owing to the fact that the victim took no care in his treatment of the injury inflicted, does not come under the application of Art. 218 P. C. . (App. 17 April 1900, p. 175).
2º. A person cannot be convicted for assault and battery causing a permanent infirmity (P.C.
Art. 218) when this permanent infirmity is solely the result of the victim's negligence in the treatment of the injury inflicted. In this case Art.220 of the P. C. is applicable.

Bribery.—The crime of bribing a public official (Arts. 89 follg. P. C.) is to be deemed completed when the gratification offered has been accepted by the official, and attempted when the offer has not been accepted. The making of an offer to “ give a gratification” constitutes an attempt to bribe, even though the gratification has not been exhibited, nor its value or nature determined. An attempt to bribe may be committed by the instrumentality of a third person (Art. 92 P. C.)

Cassation (Misapplication of lau).—The provisions concerning extenuating circumstances, contained in Art. 352 P. C., only apply to principal penalties.

In consequence the Court cannot, if it finds that there are extenuating circumstances, inflict the accessory penalty of police supervision for a term less than the minimum fixed by the article of law applied.
So a judgment is liable to Cassation which under Art. 301 P. C. sentences a person convicted of theft, as a recidivist, to police supervision for two months.
(Cass. 19 January 1901, p. 279).
